item.title: Inside the Impeachment Testimony: Dry Questions and Flares of Drama
item.description: The release of the first two transcripts of testimony taken privately in the impeachment inquiry offered the public its first glimpse of how the investigation was unfolding.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: A transcript from the House impeachment inquiry that was released to the public on Monday.

item.title: Mulvaney Summoned to Testify in Impeachment Inquiry
item.description: House investigators asked President Trump’s acting chief of staff to voluntarily appear on Capitol Hill for a deposition. It’s unlikely he’ll comply.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:description: Mick Mulvaney, the acting White House chief of staff.

item.title: Pompeo Faces Political Peril and Diplomats’ Revolt in Impeachment Inquiry
item.description: The secretary of state has been drawn deeply into the Ukraine affair, with a parade of his diplomats testifying. He is sticking by the president.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and David E. Sanger
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Confidence in Secretary of State Mike Pompeo’s leadership has plummeted among career officials.

item.title: 9 Members of Mormon Family in Mexico Are Killed in Ambush
item.description: Six children were among the victims in a massacre attributed to organized crime, relatives said. Other children were rescued, some of whom hid along a roadside.
item.dc:creator: Azam Ahmed, Elisabeth Malkin and Daniel Victor
item.category: Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)

item.title: Murder in Mexico: Mormon Families Have a Long History There
item.description: Fundamentalist religious communities have a long history in northern Mexico, dating back to settlers who practiced polygamy.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Dias
item.category: Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: A supermarket belonging to the LeBarón family in Chihuahua, Mexico, in 2009.

item.title: Election Day 2019: Which Races to Watch and What Time Polls Close
item.description: Virginia, Kentucky and Mississippi have major races that will signal the intensity of Republican support for President Trump and the degree of Democratic strength in the suburbs.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters at a polling place in Midlothian, a Western suburb of Richmond, Va., on Election Day.

item.title: A Sliver of the Electorate Could Decide 2020. Here’s What These Voters Want.
item.description: A demographically disparate group values both moderation and great change.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn

item.title: Tight Kentucky and Mississippi Governors’ Races as Trump Takes Stage
item.description: Two Republican candidates facing tough competition are hopeful that recent rallies by the president will prove decisive.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson and Richard Fausset
item.media:description: President Trump during a rally for Gov. Matt Bevin in Lexington, Ky., on Monday.

item.title: Russia Dominated Syria’s War. Now It’s Sending Mercenaries to Libya.
item.description: Moscow is plunging deeper into a war of armed drones in a strategic hot spot rich with oil, teeming with migrants and riddled with militants.
item.dc:creator: David D. Kirkpatrick
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: The addition of Russian mercenaries, part of a Kremlin campaign to reassert its influence in the region, could alter the course of Libya’s civil war.

item.title: Farm Country Feeds America. But Just Try Buying Groceries There.
item.description: An exodus of grocery stores is turning rural towns into food deserts. But some are fighting back by opening their own local markets.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Daniel Acker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Great Scott! Community Market sits in an old shoe store in Winchester, Ill.

item.title: Sean Sherman’s 10 Essential Native American Recipes
item.description: The founder of The Sioux Chef, a company devoted to Indigenous foods, created recipes to showcase tribal diversity across the lower 48 states.
item.media:credit: Marcus Nilsson for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Maggie Ruggiero. Prop Stylist: Paige Hicks.

item.title: Paris Agreement, Election Day, Mexico: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here's what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses

item.title: An Election Day Cheat Sheet to Voting
item.description: Tuesday: The New York City ballot is two pages long. Here's a guide to what's on it.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:credit: Holly Pickett for The New York Times

item.title: Who’s Actually Electable in 2020?
item.description: A new poll from The New York Times reveals which Democratic candidates may have a competitive edge against President Trump in battleground states.
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bernie Sanders, Joe Biden and Elizabeth Warren during the Democratic presidential primary debate in Westerville, Ohio last month.

item.title: SoftBank May Tighten the Reins on Start-Up Founders
item.description: After the near-collapse of WeWork, SoftBank may clamp down on the freedom afforded to the founders of companies it backs through its Vision Fund.
item.media:credit: Alessandro Di Ciommo/NurPhoto via Getty Images
item.media:description: Masayoshi Son, the SoftBank C.E.O.

item.title: How Napa Winemakers Are Confronting Climate Change
item.description: Tuesday: Climate change is remapping the world of wine. Here’s how that’s playing out in California. Also: Dating on college campuses.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Peter DaSilva for The New York Times
item.media:description: Beth Novak Milliken of Spottswoode wants Napa Valley to become a leader in the fight against climate change.

item.title: Elizabeth Warren Is Asking the Most Important Question on Health Care
item.description: How can we move from a broken system to one that covers everyone, restrains prices and improves outcomes?
item.dc:creator: Jacob S. Hacker
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Elizabeth Warren in Dubuque, Iowa, on Saturday.

item.title: Martin Scorsese: I Said Marvel Movies Aren’t Cinema. Let Me Explain.
item.description: Cinema is an art form that brings you the unexpected. In superhero movies, nothing is at risk, a director says.
item.dc:creator: Martin Scorsese
item.media:description: “It’s a perilous time in film exhibition, and there are fewer independent theaters than ever,” says Martin Scorsese.

item.title: Facebook Isn’t Just Allowing Lies, It’s Prioritizing Them
item.description: By refusing to stay out of politics, the company is building the case for its own breakup.
item.dc:creator: Tim Wu
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg before the House Financial Services Committee last month.

item.title: Wake up, Democrats
item.description: You won’t beat Trump by taking unpopular positions.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Bernie Sanders, Joe Biden and Elizabeth Warren during a 2020 Democratic presidential primary debate in Westerville, Ohio last month.

item.title: Want Anonymity? Look to Guy Fawkes
item.description: All around the world, protesters wear Guy Fawkes masks to conceal their identity in service of a cause.
item.dc:creator: Sara Barrett

item.title: The Online Cacophony of Hate Against Ilhan Omar and Rashida Tlaib
item.description: We found that they were in the cross hairs of a tiny band of Islamophobes long before Trump’s tweets.
item.dc:creator: Lawrence Pintak, Jonathan Albright and Brian J. Bowe
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representatives Ilhan Omar, Democrat of Minnesota, center, and Rashida Tlaib, left, Democrat of Michigan, at a news conference in August.

item.title: On Ukraine, Trump Is a Con Man, but He’s Also a Mark
item.description: Corrupt forces find it easy to manipulate this president.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:description: The Ukrainian oligarch Dmitry Firtash in 2016.

item.title: 5 Ballot Proposals for New York
item.description: Vote yes on Questions 1, 2, 3 and 4; no on 5.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Liberalism’s Latinx Problem
item.description: Why is Elizabeth Warren describing Latinos with a term that few would use themselves?
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elizabeth Warren at a rally in Austin, Tex., in September.

item.title: Attack of the Wall Street Snowflakes
item.description: Why can’t financial tycoons handle criticism?
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times

item.title: An Invitation to Readers: Variations on a Letter
item.description: Be creative. Send us a limerick, haiku, fractured nursery rhyme, whatever strikes your fancy.

item.title: Knowing Paris by Its Bridges
item.description: Spanning the Seine, of steel, stone and wood, the city’s many bridges offer lessons in history, architecture — and romance.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Sciolino
item.media:credit: Joann Pai for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Pont Alexandre III is the most elegant bridge in Paris.

item.title: Life After Prison, on YouTube
item.description: Christina Randall wanted to become a social worker once she got out of jail. She didn’t expect to reach so many people.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Tait
item.media:credit: Eve Edelheit for The New York Times
item.media:description: Christina Randall, 35, makes YouTube videos about life in prison and the challenges of re-entry. She sees her channel as a platform for education and reform.

item.title: Holiday Movies 2019: Here’s What’s Coming Soon to Theaters
item.description: The “Star Wars” Skywalker saga is coming to an end, “Frozen” is getting a sequel and “The Shining” characters are baaaaaack. Here’s what you need to know about the season in cinema.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg
item.category: Danger Close: The Battle of Long Tan (Movie)
Scandalous: The Untold Story of the National Enquirer (Movie)
To Kid or Not to Kid (Movie)
A Beautiful Day in the Neighborhood (Movie)
The Body Remembers When the World Broke Open (Movie)

The Death and Life of John F Donovan (Movie)
The Invisible Life of Euridice Gusmao (Movie)
Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker (Movie)
What She Said: The Art of Pauline Kael (Movie)

item.title: After Deadspin Chaos, an Executive Exits
item.description: G/O Media’s editorial director, Paul Maidment, follows the staff of Deadspin out the door.
item.dc:creator: Katie Robertson
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The Washington Post, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Deadspin’s entire editorial team resigned last week.

item.title: It’s Back: 8chan Returns Online
item.description: The anonymous message board went back online over the weekend as 8kun, three months after being booted off the internet.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger
item.media:description: 8chan re-emerged over the weekend under a new name, 8kun.

item.title: Trump Vowed to Shrink the Trade Gap. It Keeps Growing.
item.description: The overall trade deficit continued to widen in the first nine months of 2019, suggesting that the global trade wars haven’t had the desired effect.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: President Trump has pointed to the trade deficit — an excess of American imports over exports — as a sign of a hollowed-out manufacturing sector.

item.title: He Wanted Cold Medicine, but CVS Rejected His Puerto Rican ID
item.description: CVS has apologized after a college student in Indiana was unable to buy cold medicine because employees would not accept his identification.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:description: A Facebook post by Arlene Payano Burgos about her son’s experience had been shared more than 10,000 times.

item.title: Victim of Milwaukee Acid Attack Says He Was Told to ‘Go Back to Your Country’
item.description: Mahud Villalaz, a U.S. citizen who received second-degree burns to his face, recalled his attacker saying, “You came here to invade.”
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:credit: Lauren Justice for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mahud Villalaz received second-degree burns to his face after he was confronted by a man he says accused him of being in the country illegally.

item.title: Is Aramco Worth $2 Trillion? And Other Crucial I.P.O. Questions
item.description: The valuation of the giant oil producer remains a critical question in the wake its decision to go public.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:description: Saudi Aramco’s Shaybah oilfield in 2018. Aramco was the world’s most profitable company by far last year.

item.title: ‘A Very Dangerous Game’: In Latin America, Embattled Leaders Lean on Generals
item.description: Presidents are increasingly asking militaries to bail them out of crises, surfacing painful memories in a region where many grew up under military rule.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher

item.title: What India Looks Like When the Air Turns to Poison
item.description: The toxic New Delhi skies are caused in part by the burning of fields, and officials have begun restricting car use, shutting primary schools and halting construction projects.
item.dc:creator: Kai Schultz
item.media:description: Smog blanketed a gathering for the Hindu religious festival Chhath Puja in New Delhi on Sunday.

item.title: The Subway Is in Financial Crisis. Are 500 More Police Officers Needed?
item.description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo wants to spend more than $50 million a year on new police officers, even though the transit agency is facing a financial crisis. Opponents say the system is already overly policed.
item.dc:creator: Emma G. Fitzsimmons
item.media:description: Transit groups say that instead of adding police, the governor should focus resources on modernizing the subway.

item.title: How to Eat Alone (and Like It)
item.description: Table for one? It’s not as bad as it sounds. Here’s how to dine by yourself and enjoy every bite.
item.dc:creator: Jess McHugh

item.title: How to Give People Advice They’ll Be Delighted to Take
item.description: Evaluate, collaborate and support.
item.dc:creator: Anna Goldfarb

item.title: Why You Should Find Time to Be Alone With Yourself
item.description: Don’t confuse loneliness with time by yourself.
item.dc:creator: Micaela Marini Higgs

item.title: 16 Useful Gems in Apple’s New iOS 13
item.description: iOS 13, Apple’s new operating system for the iPhone, comes with tons of new tools under the hood. Here are some of the most helpful.
item.dc:creator: David Pogue

item.title: Gear to Make Room in a Tiny Kitchen
item.description: I’ve tested dozens of items, and here’s what’s best for under $40 — a fridge wall rack, cup hooks, a magnetic knife strip, and more.
item.dc:creator: Michael Sullivan

item.title: Lindsay Peoples Wagner on Her First Year as Editor of Teen Vogue
item.description: How she got there, what she’s learned and why she is upending things.
item.dc:creator: Iman Stevenson
item.media:description: Lindsay Peoples Wagner in the front row at the Christopher John Rogers show during New York Fashion Week.

item.title: Wedding Photography Collides With ‘Ruin Porn’
item.description: Abandoned buildings are the aesthetic choice for some couples and their wedding photography.
item.dc:creator: Michael T. Luongo

item.title: Knicks Search for the Right Lineup. But Is There One?
item.description: When evaluating the team’s point guard situation and roster mishmash, it’s hard not to be reminded they are a result of management misadventures.
item.dc:creator: Harvey Araton
item.media:description: Kings point guard De’Aaron Fox credits starting 60 games as a rookie in 2017-18 with boosting his confidence. He is averaging 18.6 points and 6.3 assists a game this season.

item.title: No, Sean Spicer Really Can’t Dance
item.description: He has consistently been the worst performer on “Dancing With the Stars.” So why is he still on?
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas
item.media:description: Sean Spicer and Lindsay Arnold on the first week of “Dancing With the Stars.”

item.title: How Two Black Women a Century Apart Experience Racism
item.description: Margaret Wilkerson Sexton’s new novel, “The Revisioners,” is told from the perspectives of a freed slave and her present-day descendant.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Powell Watts

item.title: Microsoft Surface Pro X Review: Powerful Computer, but So-So Tablet
item.description: With its new Surface, Microsoft has made progress blending the best of mobile devices and personal computers. But it falls short in offering a fingertip-friendly experience for tablets.
item.dc:creator: Brian X. Chen
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: The new Microsoft Surface Pro X.

item.title: Stalking the Endangered Wax Palm
item.description: Colombia’s national tree, the wax palm, is endangered. Now, with decades of guerrilla war in retreat, scientists are rediscovering vast forests and racing to study and protect them.
item.dc:creator: Jennie Erin Smith and Federico Rios Escobar

item.title: Screen Use Tied to Children’s Brain Development
item.description: In a study, preschoolers who used screens less had better language skills.
item.dc:creator: Perri Klass, M.D.

item.title: U.S. Blames Drug Shortages on Low Prices and a ‘Broken Marketplace’
item.description: A government task force suggested that providers pay more for lifesaving generics and that drug makers receive quality ratings.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: Generic drugs like vincristine, critical in the treatment of the most common childhood cancer, are among the medications in short supply in recent years.

item.title: New Library Is a $41.5 Million Masterpiece. But About Those Stairs.
item.description: “It’s chaos,” said one of the children’s librarians.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman

item.title: I Got Access to My Secret Consumer Score. Now You Can Get Yours, Too.
item.description: Little-known companies are amassing your data — like food orders and Airbnb messages — and selling the analysis to clients. Here’s how to get a copy of what they have on you.
item.dc:creator: Kashmir Hill

item.title: As Men Are Canceled, So Too Their Magazine Subscriptions
item.description: The boys’ club of glossy publishing confronts an identity crisis.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
